case_name: Punjab National Bank Limited v. Kharbanda

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 103 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 103 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated August 2, 1960 of Central Government Labour Court at Delhi in L.C.A. No. 80 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 2,1960, of the Central Government Labour Court at Delhi in L. C. A. No. 80 of 1960.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by WANCHOO, J. on February 2, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. February 2. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal by special leave in an industrial matter.

facts.text: Respondent Kharbanda is a supervisor in Punjab National Bank Limited, the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Kharbanda is a supervisor in the Punjab National Bank Limited which is the appellant before us.

facts.text: Dispute relates to fixation of respondent's salary under Sastry Award.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute relates to the fixation of his salary in accordance with the All India Industrial Tribunal  Bank Disputes  Award  hereinafter

facts.text: Respondent applied to Central Labour Court, Delhi under s. 33-C(2) of Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent made an application to the Central Labour Court, Delhi, under s. 33-C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, No. XIV of 1947,

facts.text: Respondent claimed entitled to Rs. 6,428.28 nP. as arrears upto date of application due to wrong fixation of basic salary under Sastry Award.

anchor.surface_text: his case was that he was entitled to certain benefits capable of being companyputed in terms of money under the Sastry Award, but the appellant had made a wrong calculation in fixing his basic salary. Therefore, the respondent prayed that the benefit to which he was entitled by fixation of his basic salary companyrectly should be companyputed in terms of money and determined by the Labour Court. His case further was that when his basic salary was rightly fixed under Sastry Award he would be entitled to a sum of Rs. 6,428.28 nP. as arrears upto the date of his application.

facts.text: Appellant contended application not maintainable under s. 33-C(2) and lacked jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The application was opposed on behalf of the appellant and two companytentions were raised to meet the case put forward by the respondent. In the first place it was urged that the application was number maintainable under s. 33-C 2  of the Act and the Labour Court had numberjurisdiction to decide it

facts.text: Appellant contended their fixation of basic salary was correct.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it was urged that the manner in which the appellant had fixed the basic salary was companyrect and there was therefore numberforce in the companytention of the respondent that he was entitled to certain benefits of which he had been deprived and which should be calculated by the labour companyrt.

facts.text: Sen Tribunal appointed in June 1949, award set aside by Supreme Court in 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Originally another tribunal known as the Sen Tribunal was appointed in June 1949 to go into the disputes between various banks all over the companyntry and their employees. The Sen Tribunal made an award after an exhaustive inquiry but on appeal to this Court the said award was set aside in 1951.

facts.text: Act II of 1951 passed to freeze certain provisions of Sen award.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Act II of 1951 was passed as a temporary measure for freezing certain provisions of the said award in order to prevent the spread of the prevalent unrest amongst the bank employees in question.

facts.text: Sastry Tribunal referred by Central Government in January 1952, award published April 20, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The said dispute was then referred by the Central Government to the Sastry tribunal in January 1952. This tribunal held an elaborate inquiry and made its award which was published on April 20, 1953.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal confirmed Sastry award substantially on April 28, 1954 with modifications.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals were preferred by the banks and their employees against the said award before the Labour Appellate Tribunal, and on April 28, 1954, the Appellate Tribunal substantially companyfirmed the recommendations and directions of the Sastry tribunal with certain modifications.

facts.text: Provisions of Sastry award regarding matter in controversy remained unmodified, admitted by parties.

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeal, we are number companycerned with the further history of the dispute, for it is admitted that the provisions of the Sastry award with respect to the matter in companytroversy before us have remained unmodified

facts.text: Sastry award provided one scale for clerks in Class A, area I: Rs. 85 to Rs. 280.

anchor.surface_text: The Sastry tribunal decided after companysidering the matter from all aspects to provide only one scale for clerks in all banks, though banks themselves were divided into four classes and the places where the banks were situate were divided into three areas. In the present appeal we are companycerned with Class A, area I, for which the grade provided was from Rs. 85 to Rs. 280 with varying increments  see para 119 of the award  to which it is unnecessary to refer.

facts.text: Sastry award granted special allowance of Rs. 50/- for supervisors in A class banks in area I (para 164).

anchor.surface_text: One such class of special posts with which the Sastry award was companycerned was the class of supervisors to which the respondent belongs and it provided a special allowance of Rs. 50/- in the case of A class banks in area I for supervisors by para. 164 thereof.

facts.text: Sastry award para 292 cl. 7: Workmen joining after Jan 31, 1950 fitted point-to-point into new scale, basic pay not less than under corresponding pre-Sen scale.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provision with respect to such employees is cl.  7  of para 292 which reads as follows -  7 . The workman shall be fitted into the new scale of pay on a point-to-point basis as though it had been in force since he joined the service of the bank, provided that his adjusted basic pay is number less than what it would be under a point to-point adjustment on the companyresponding pre-Sen scale.

facts.text: Respondent appointed as supervisor by appellant on April 22, 1951 on basic salary Rs. 120/- per mensem.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the respondent was appointed as a superiors by the appellant on April 22, 1951 on the basic salary of Rs. 120/- per mensem.

facts.text: Pre-appointment, supervisors scale was Rs. 120-8-200-EB-10-300; graduate clerks Rs. 75-5-120-8-200.

anchor.surface_text: At that time the basic scale for supervisors was Rs. 120-8-200-EB-10-300 while there was a basic scale for graduate clerks etc. of Rs. 75-5-120-8-200. The respondent was appointed on the initial basic salary of Rs. 120/- per mensem.

facts.text: Respondent claims basic salary fixed under para 292(7) using supervisors scale for proviso; appellant claims using graduate clerks scale.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute between the parties is that the respondent claims that his basic salary should be fixed under para 292 7  according to the supervisors scale for the purposes of the proviso while the appellant claims that it can only be fixed at the highest on the scale for graduate clerks, and the appellant fixed the respondents pay on that basis, and that led to the respondents making the present application under s. 33-C 2  of the Act.

facts.text: Labour Court found in favour of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal has found in favour of the respondent.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant therefore applied for special leave which was granted and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Industrial tribunal awarded on April 4, 1957 that supervisors are workmen in dispute with this bank.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the respondent companytends that supervisors are workmen, as has been held in a dispute between this very bank and its supervisors, referred to an industrial tribunal which gave an award on April 4, 1957,

facts.text: Supreme Court in Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Their Workmen observed supervisors are workmen.

anchor.surface_text: see the observations of this Court in the Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Their Workmen   1 ,

facts.text: Appellant admits supervisors, accountants etc. are generally workmen under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection, we may incidentally add that it is number disputed by the appellant that its supervisors, accountants and accounts in-charge are generally workmen under the Act, though some may number be so.

facts.text: Appellant had nine scales for workmen, including supervisors grade.

anchor.surface_text: The difficulty, so far as the appellant is companycerned, arose on account of the fact that the appellant had nine scales which applied to workmen of all kinds beginning with peons and chaukidars and ending with accountants and accounts in-charge. Three of these scales were for what may be called subordinate staff under the Sastry award while six were for what is clerical staff under the Sastry award. These six included the grade of supervisors.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Labour Court had jurisdiction under s. 33-C(2) for computing disputed monetary benefit under award.

anchor.surface_text: As in this case, the Sastry award had companyferred a benefit on the respondent and those like him by providing for fixation of pay in the new scale, even though that benefit may be monetary and there was a dispute between the parties as to the amount of that benefit, it was open to the respondent to apply to the labour companyrt for companyputation of that benefit in terms of money, and the labour companyrt would have jurisdiction to entertain the application and companypute the amount due on the basis of the benefit companyferred by the award.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds respondent's basic pay to be fixed using supervisors scale as corresponding pre-Sen scale.

anchor.surface_text: Now if the supervisors scale was the scale of a workman previous to the Sen award then it must be held to be a companyresponding scale for the purpose of fixation so far as the respondent is companycerned, irrespective of the name by which this class of workmen was designated in this particular bank.

facts.text: Labour Court's view on fixation correct, no dispute on amount once principle fixed.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what we have said, the supervisors scale being a scale for workmen in this bank, the respondent is right in his claim that his basic pay cannot be reduced below what it would be under a point-to-point adjustment on the companyresponding scale which he was drawing before the Sen award, in this bank as a workman. In this view of the matter the view taken by the labour companyrt is companyrect. Once the principle is fixed, there is numberdispute as the amount due to the respondent.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 2,1960, of the Central Government Labour Court at Delhi in L. C. A. No. 80 of 1960.
1962. February 2. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal by special leave in an industrial matter.
The appellant therefore applied for special leave which was granted and that is how the matter has come up before us.
The respondent made an application to the Central Labour Court, Delhi, under s. 33-C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, No. XIV of 1947,

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for computation of monetary benefits by Labour Court

anchor.surface_text: The application was opposed on behalf of the appellant and two contentions were raised to meet the case put forward by the respondent. In the first place it was urged that the application was not maintainable under s. 33-C 2  of the Act and the Labour Court had no jurisdiction to decide it

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for computation of monetary benefits by Labour Court

anchor.surface_text: and that led to the respondents making the present application under s. 33-C 2  of the Act. The tribunal has found in favour of the respondent.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for computation of monetary benefits by Labour Court

anchor.surface_text: The first question therefore that falls for decision is whether such an application can be made under s. 33- C 2  of the Act, Section 33-C  2  reads as follows - Where any workman is entitled to receive from the employer any benefit which is capable of being computed in terms of money, the amount at which such benefit should be computed may, subject to any rules that may, made under this Act, be determined by such Labour Court as may be specified in this behalf by the appropriate Government, and the amount so determined may be recovered as provided for in sub-section  1 .

concepts.interpretation: Applies to benefits capable of being computed in terms of money, including disputed monetary benefits under awards requiring calculation or computation (e.g., pay fixation), not limited to non-monetary benefits needing conversion; distinguished from s.33C(1) where amount is undisputed and already computed.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: be made under s. 33- C 2  of the Act, Section 33-C  2  reads as follows - Where any workman is entitled to receive from the employer any benefit whic

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for computation of monetary benefits by Labour Court

anchor.surface_text: Further, if we compare sub-s. 1  with sub-s 2  of this section, it will appear that sub-s. 1  applies to cases where any money is due to a workman from an employer under a settlement or an award or under the provisions of Chap. VA and that contemplated that the amount is already computed or calculated or at any rate there can be no dispute about the computation or calculation while sub-s. 2

concepts.interpretation: Applies where monetary amount due under settlement/award is already computed without dispute.

anchor.surface_text: It may be added that s. 33-C was put in the Act for the purposes of execution in 1956 after the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act,  48 of 1950  was repealed in that year. The Appellate Tribunal Act contained s. 20 which provided for execution of awards and was in terms almost similar to s. 33 C.

concepts.interpretation: Predecessor provision similar to s.33C for execution of awards; interpreted to cover monetary benefits requiring computation.

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeal, we are not concerned with the further history of the dispute, for it is admitted that the provisions of the Sastry award with respect to the matter in controversy before us have remained unmodified when finally the dispute was set at rest by the Industrial Disputes  Banking Companies  Decision Act,  XLI of 1955 .

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter Act II of 1951 was passed as a temporary measure for freezing certain provisions of the said award in order to prevent the spread of the prevalent unrest amongst the bank employees in question.

The workman shall be fitted into the new scale of pay on a point-to-point basis as though it had been in force since he joined the service of the bank, provided that his adjusted basic pay is not less than what it would be under a point to-point adjustment on the corresponding pre-Sen scale.

Their Workmen   1 , In this connection, we may incidentally add that it is not disputed by the appellant that its supervisors, accountants and accounts in-charge are generally workmen under the Act, though some may not be so.

VA and that contemplated that the amount is already computed or calculated or at any rate there can be no dispute about the computation or calculation while sub-s. 2  applies to cases where though the monetary benefit has been conferred on a workman under an award, it has not been calculated or computed in the award itself,

issues.text: whether such an application can be made under s. 33-C(2) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellant therefore applied for special leave which was granted and that is how the matter has come up before us. The first question therefore that falls for decision is whether such an application can be made under s. 33- C 2  of the Act, Section 33-C  2  reads as follows -

issues.text: as to how the basic salary should be fixed

anchor.surface_text: As in this case, the Sastry award had conferred a benefit on the respondent and those like him by providing for fixation of pay in the new scale, even though that benefit may be monetary and there was a dispute between the parties as to the amount of that benefit, it was open to the respondent to apply to the labour court for computation of that benefit in terms of money, and the labour court would have jurisdiction to entertain the application and compute the amount due on the basis of the benefit conferred by the award. This brings us to the next question, namely, as to how the basic salary should be fixed.

issues.text: whether the application was maintainable under s. 33-C(2) of the Act and the Labour Court had jurisdiction to decide it

anchor.surface_text: The application was opposed on behalf of the appellant and two contentions were raised to meet the case put forward by the respondent. In the first place it was urged that the application was not maintainable under s. 33-C 2  of the Act and the Labour Court had no jurisdiction to decide it Secondly, it was urged that the manner in which the appellant had fixed the basic salary was correct and there was therefore no force in the contention of the respondent that he was entitled to certain benefits of which he had been deprived and which should be calculated by the labour court.

issues.text: whether the manner in which the appellant had fixed the basic salary was correct

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it was urged that the manner in which the appellant had fixed the basic salary was correct and there was therefore no force in the contention of the respondent that he was entitled to certain benefits of which he had been deprived and which should be calculated by the labour court. Before we deal with the two points which arise in the present appeal we may refer to the provisions of the Sastry Award out of which the present dispute arises.

arguments.claim: s. 33-C(2) deals only with non-monetary benefits which could be computed in terms of money by conversion

anchor.surface_text: It is contended on behalf of the appellant that s. 33-C 2  deals only with such cases where the workman is entitled to receive from the employer any benefit which is non-monetary but which could be computed in terms of money. It is said that it is only in such a case where the workman claims a non-monetary benefit from his employer that he can apply to the labour court for converting the value of this non-monetary benefit into money and computing the amount due in terms of money.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e appellant, there would be numbersense in companyputing monetary benefits in terms on money. But this companytention overlooks the fact that the word

arguments.court_reasoning: Word 'computed' means calculate, not convert; no reason to exclude monetary benefits; dictionary meanings support inclusion

arguments.claim: Benefit need not necessarily be non-monetary; any benefit under award requiring computation can be subject of application under s.33C(2)

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it has been contended on behalf of the respondent that the benefit to which a workman may be entitled need not necessarily be non-monetary and that any benefit to which he is entitled under an award if it requires computation can be the subject-matter of an application under s. 33-C  2 . Reliance has been placed on behalf of the respondent in this connection on a course of decisions by the industrial tribunals and the High Courts where the meaning of the word benefit in sub-s. 2  has not been confined to non-monetary benefits only.

VA and that contemplated that the amount is already computed or calculated or at any rate there can be no dispute about the computation or calculation while sub-s. 2  applies to cases where though the monetary benefit has been conferred on a workman under an award,

arguments.claim: Sastry tribunal fixed one scale for all clerks and supervisors are clerks so corresponding scale is clerks scale; only certain grades treated as clerks

anchor.surface_text: The main emphasis on behalf of the appellant in this connection is on the word corresponding appearing in cl.  7  of para. 292. It is urged that the Sastry tribunal fixed one scale for all clerks and as supervisors are clerks the respondent could only be considered as belonging to the corresponding scale for clerks in the appellant-bank for the application of the proviso and thereafter he would be entitled to the special allowance of Rs. 50/- per mensem.

holdings.text: Looking therefore to the words of the sub-section and the previous decisions with respect to them we are of opinion that the word benefit used in sub-s. 2 is not confined merely to non-monetary benefit which could be converted in terms of money but is concerned with all kinds of benefits, whether monetary or non-monetary, to which a workman may be entitled, say, for example, under an award and that the sub-section comes into play when the benefits have to be computed or calculated and there is a dispute as to the calculation or computation.

anchor.surface_text: Looking therefore to the words of the sub-section and the previous decisions with respect to them we are of opinion that the word benefit used in sub-s. 2 is not confined merely to non-monetary benefit which could be converted in terms of money but is concerned with all kinds of benefits, whether monetary or non

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets 'any benefit which is capable of being computed in terms of money' broadly using dictionary meanings of 'benefit' and 'computed'; distinguishes from 'converted'; harmonious construction with s.33C(1); follows prior tribunal and High Court decisions; historical context from predecessor s.20.

holdings.text: As in this case, the Sastry award had conferred a benefit on the respondent and those like him by providing for fixation of pay in the new scale, even though that benefit may be monetary and there was a dispute between the parties as to the amount of that benefit, it was open to the respondent to apply to the labour court for computation of that benefit in terms of money, and the labour court would have jurisdiction to entertain the application and compute the amount due on the basis of the benefit conferred by the award.

anchor.surface_text: As in this case, the Sastry award had conferred a benefit on the respondent and those like him by providing for fixation of pay in the new scale, even though that benefit may be monetary and there was a dispute between the parties as to the amount of that benefit, it was open to the respondent to apply to the labour court fo

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies broad interpretation of s.33C(2) to facts: disputed pay fixation benefit under Sastry award is monetary but requires computation due to disagreement on method.

holdings.text: Now if the supervisors scale was the scale of a workman previous to the Sen award then it must be held to be a corresponding scale for the purpose of fixation so far as the respondent is concerned, irrespective of the name by which this class of workmen was designated in this particular bank.

anchor.surface_text: Now if the supervisors scale was the scale of a workman previous to the Sen award then it must be held to be a corresponding scale for the purpose of fixation so far as the respondent is concerned, irrespective of the name by which this class of workmen was designated in this particular bank.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Para 292 cl.7 requires point-to-point fitting with proviso protecting basic pay not less than on 'corresponding pre-Sen scale'; correspondence based on actual workman scale drawn pre-Sen, not standardized clerk label under Sastry.

holdings.text: We have already pointed out that it has been already held between this very bank and its workmen that supervisors are workmen and therefore the supervisors scale in this bank was a workmens scale therefore when the fixation of pay has to be made under cl. 7 we have to find out the corresponding workmens scale in the case of the respondent at a time before the Sen award was made and that in our opinion can only be the supervisors scale, for supervisors have been held to be workmen between the parties to the present dispute.

anchor.surface_text: We have already pointed out that it has been already held between this very bank and its workmen that supervisors are workmen and therefore the supervisors scale in this bank was a workmens scale therefore when the fixation of pay has to be made under cl. 7 we have to find out the corresponding workmens scale in

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on prior industrial tribunal award (1957) and Supreme Court observations in Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Their Workmen; appellant's admission that supervisors generally workmen; para 292 applies to 'workmen generally'.

holdings.text: In view of what we have said, the supervisors scale being a scale for workmen in this bank, the respondent is right in his claim that his basic pay cannot be reduced below what it would be under a point-to-point adjustment on the corresponding scale which he was drawing before the Sen award, in this bank as a workman. In this view of the matter the view taken by the labour court is correct. Once the principle is fixed, there is no dispute as the amount due to the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what we have said, the supervisors scale being a scale for workmen in this bank, the respondent is right in his claim that his basic pay cannot be reduced below what it would be under a point-to-point adjustment on the corresponding scale which he was drawing before the Sen award, in this bank as a workman. In this view of the matter the view taken by the labour court is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concludes application of para 292(7) to facts affirms respondent's entitlement and Labour Court's computation; no further dispute on quantum.

precedents.cited_proposition: Section 33-C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act is not confined to non-monetary benefits

precedents.citation: Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Their Workmen   1

anchor.surface_text: Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Their Workmen   1

precedents.case_name: Punjab National Bank Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: Supervisors of the appellant bank are workmen under the Industrial Disputes Act

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the Sastry award provided for a social pay for certain employees including supervisors has numberrelevance on the question of correspondence which has to be worked out under cl.  7  in order to find out the basic pay for purposes of fixation. In view of what we have said, the supervisors scale being a scale for workmen in this bank, the respondent is right in his claim that his basic pay cannot be reduced below what it would be under a point-to-point adjustment on the companyresponding scale which he was drawing before the Sen award, in this bank as a workman. In this view of the matter the view taken by the labour companyrt is companyrect.

outcome.relief_summary: Labour Court decision upheld; respondent entitled to point-to-point adjustment on supervisors pre-Sen scale for basic pay fixation under Sastry Award and arrears of Rs. 6,428.28
directions: Labour Court to compute the amount due as per the principle laid down
